speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Open Market Committee concluded a two-day meeting earlier today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Based on its review of recent economic and financial developments, the Committee sees the economy continuing to grow at a moderate pace, notwithstanding the strong headwinds created by current federal fiscal policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The labor market has continued to improve, with gains in private payroll employment averaging about 200,000 jobs per month over the past six months.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Job gains, along with the strengthening housing market, have in turn contributed to increases in consumer confidence and supported household spending.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, at 7.6 percent, the unemployment rate remains elevated, as do rates of underemployment and long-term unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Overall, the Committee believes the downside risks to the outlook for the economy and the labor market have diminished since the fall, but we will continue to evaluate economic conditions and risks as they evolve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Inflation has been running below the Committee’s longer-run objective of 2 percent for some time and has been a bit softer recently.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee believes that the recent softness partly reflects transitory factors, and with longer-term inflation expectations remaining stable, the Committee expects inflation to move back towards this 2 percent longer-term objective over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We will, however, be closely monitoring these developments as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In conjunction with this meeting, the 19 participants in our policy discussion—the 7 Board members and the 12 Reserve Bank presidents—submitted individual economic projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As always, each participant’s projections are conditioned on his or her own view of appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Generally, the projections of individual participants show they expect moderate growth, picking up over time, and gradual progress towards levels of unemployment and inflation consistent with the Federal Reserve’s statutory mandate to foster maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In brief, participants’ projections for economic growth have a central tendency of 2.3 to 2.6 percent for 2013, rising to 2.9 to 3.6 percent in 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The central tendency of their projections of the unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of this year is 7.2 to 7.3 percent, declining to 5.8 to 6.2 percent in the final quarter of 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most participants see inflation gradually increasing from its current low level toward the Committee’s longer-run objective; the central tendency of their projections for inflation is 0.8 to 1.2 percent for this year and 1.6 to 2.0 percent for 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Before turning to today’s policy decision, let me say a few words about the Federal Reserve’s strategy for normalizing policy in the long run.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In the minutes of its June 2011 meeting, the Committee set forth principles that it intended to follow when the time came to normalize policy and the size and the structure of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As part of prudent planning, we have been reviewing these principles in recent meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We expect those discussions to continue and intend to provide further information at an appropriate time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For today, I will note that, in the view of most participants, the broad principles set out in June 2011 remain applicable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One difference is worth mentioning.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: While participants continue to think that, in the long run, the Federal Reserve’s portfolio should consist predominantly of Treasury securities, a strong majority now expects that the Committee will not sell agency mortgage-backed securities during the process of normalizing monetary policy, although in the longer run, limited sales could be used to reduce or eliminate residual MBS holdings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I emphasize that, given the outlook and the Committee’s policy guidance, these matters are unlikely to be relevant to actual policy for quite a while.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me turn now to current policy issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: With unemployment still elevated and inflation below the Committee’s longer-run objective, the Committee is continuing its highly accommodative policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you know, in normal times, the Committee eases monetary policy by lowering the target for the short-term policy interest rate, the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, the target range for the federal funds rate, currently at 0 to ¼ percent, cannot meaningfully be reduced further.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thus, we are providing policy accommodation through two alternative methods: first, by communicating to the public the Committee’s plans for setting the federal funds rate target over the medium term, and, second, by purchasing and holding Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me discuss a few key points regarding each of these two policy tools.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: First, today the Committee reaffirmed its expectation that the current exceptionally low range for the funds rate will be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6½ percent so long as inflation and inflation expectations remain well behaved in the senses described in the FOMC statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As I have noted frequently, the phrase “at least as long” in the Committee’s interest rate guidance is important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The economic conditions we have set out as preceding any future rate increase are thresholds, not triggers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, assuming that inflation is near our objective at that time, as expected, a decline in the unemployment rate to 6½ percent would not lead automatically to an increase in the federal funds rate target, but rather would indicate only that it was appropriate for the Committee to consider whether the broader economic outlook justified such an increase.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: All else equal, the more subdued the outlook for inflation at that time, the more patient the Committee would likely be in making that assessment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In the projections submitted for this meeting, 14 of 19 FOMC participants indicated that they expect the first increase in the target for the federal funds rate to occur in 2015, and one expected the first increase to incur in 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Moreover, so long as the economy remains short of maximum employment, inflation remains near our longer-run objective, and inflation expectations remain well anchored, increases in the target for the federal funds rate, once they begin, are likely to be gradual, consistent with the Committee’s balanced approach to meeting its employment and price stability objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The purpose of this forward guidance about policy is to assure households and businesses that monetary policy will continue to support the recovery even as the pace of economic growth and job creation picks up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Importantly, as our statement notes, the Committee expects a considerable interval of time to pass between when the Committee will cease adding accommodation through asset purchases and the time when the Committee will begin to reduce accommodation by moving the federal funds rate target toward more normal levels.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The second policy tool being employed by the Committee is asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Specifically, the Committee has been purchasing $40 billion per month in agency mortgage-backed securities and $45 billion per month in Treasury securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: When our program of asset purchases was initiated last September, the Committee stated the goal of promoting a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market in the context of price stability and noted it would also be taking appropriate account of the efficacy and costs of the program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Today the Committee made no changes to the purchase program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Although the Committee left the pace of purchases unchanged at today’s meeting, it has stated that it may vary the pace of purchases as economic conditions evolve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Any such change would reflect the incoming data and their implications for the outlook, as well as the cumulative progress made toward the Committee’s objectives since the program began in September.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Going forward, the economic outcomes that the Committee sees as most likely involve continuing gains in labor markets, supported by moderate growth that picks up over the next several quarters as the near-term restraint from fiscal policy and other headwinds diminishes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We also see inflation moving back toward our 2 percent objective over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If the incoming data are broadly consistent with this forecast, the Committee currently anticipates that it would be appropriate to moderate the monthly pace of purchases later this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And if the subsequent data remain broadly aligned with our current expectations for the economy, we would continue to reduce the pace of purchases in measured steps through the first half of next year, ending purchases around midyear.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In this scenario, when asset purchases ultimately come to an end, the unemployment rate would likely be in the vicinity of 7 percent, with solid economic growth supporting further job gains, a substantial improvement from the 8.1 percent unemployment rate that prevailed when the Committee announced this program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would like to emphasize once more the point that our policy is in no way predetermined and will depend on the incoming data and the evolution of the outlook as well as on the cumulative progress toward our objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If conditions improve faster than expected, the pace of asset purchases could be reduced somewhat more quickly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If the outlook becomes less favorable, on the other hand, or if financial conditions are judged to be inconsistent with further progress in the labor markets, reductions in the pace of purchases could be delayed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Indeed, should it be needed, the Committee would be prepared to employ all of its tools, including an increase in the pace of purchases for a time, to promote a return to maximum employment in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s also worth noting here that, even if a modest reduction in the pace of asset purchases occurs, we would not be shrinking the Federal Reserve’s portfolio of securities, but only slowing the pace at which we are adding to the portfolio while continuing to reinvest principal payments and proceeds from maturing holdings as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: These large and growing holdings will continue to put downward pressure on longer-term interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To use the analogy of driving an automobile, any slowing in the pace of purchases will be akin to letting up a bit on the gas pedal as the car picks up speed, not to beginning to apply the brakes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I will close by drawing again the important distinction between the Committee’s decisions about adjusting the pace of asset purchases and its forward guidance regarding the target for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As I mentioned, the current level of the federal funds rate target is likely to remain appropriate for a considerable period after asset purchases are concluded.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To return to the driving analogy, if the incoming data support the view that the economy is able to sustain a reasonable cruising speed, we will ease the pressure on the accelerator by gradually reducing the pace of purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, any need to consider applying the brakes by raising short-term rates is still far in the future.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In any case, no matter how conditions may evolve, the Federal Reserve remains committed to fostering substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’d be glad to take your questions.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman with CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I hate to use my question to ask you to clarify something, but when you said gradually reduce purchases, beginning later this year and ending it next year when the unemployment rate hits 7 percent—what is that?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is that a decision by the FOMC?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is that an intention that— CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: That is—we had a good discussion of that issue today, and we haven’t had—obviously, there’s no change, there’s no change in policy involved here, there’s simply a clarification, helping people to think about where policy will evolve.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: So, it was thought that it might be best for me to explain that to this group and answer questions.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Future policy statements may include elements of this, but it’s not a policy change.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I’m just trying to explain how are—how we’re making a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market, how we’re making that concrete, and how we’re thinking about the potential future of the program given alternative policy and economic developments.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: So there is no consensus on that?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: That’s not a vote of the FOMC, that’s not a plan that’s written down some place or—?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It represents the consensus of the FOMC, yes.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: If you could just—the question I was going to ask was, could you give us some information on “substantial improvement”?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is that the unemployment rate coming down by itself to 7 percent, or are there other factors involved, and is it “substantial” compared to the fall?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is that when— CHAIRMAN BERNANKE.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Well, there are many factors that we look at when trying to judge the state of the labor market.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: As you know, we look at participation, payrolls, a variety of other data, but the 7 percent unemployment rate is indicative of the kind of progress we’d like to make in order to be able to say that we’ve reached substantial progress.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Jon Hilsenrath from the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Mr. Chairman, there’s an undercurrent of optimism in your forecast and your statement—in the policy statement today.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: For instance, the unemployment rate forecast comes down to 6.5 to 6.8 percent next year.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: It’s the case that the Fed has overestimated the economy’s growth rate very often in the past during this recovery, so—and we’ve gone through a period in the first half of the year with pretty subdued growth.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: So I would like to hear you explain where this optimism comes from and how confident you are that these expectations are going to be met.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, the fundamentals look a little better to us.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, the housing sector, which has been a drag on growth since the crisis, is now, obviously, a support to growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s not only creating construction jobs, but as house prices rise, increased household wealth supports consumption spending, consumer sentiment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: State and local governments, who have been a major drag, are now coming to a position where they no longer have to lay off large numbers of workers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Generally speaking, financial conditions are improving.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The main drag, or the main headwind, to growth this year is, as you know, is the federal fiscal policy, which the CBO estimates is something on the order of 1½ percentage points of growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And our judgment is that, you know, given that very heavy headwind, the fact that the economy is still moving ahead at at least a moderate pace, is indicative that the underlying factors are improving.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so we’ll see how that evolves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Obviously, we haven’t seen the full effect yet of the fiscal policy changes; we’ll want to see how that evolves as we get through that fiscal impact.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we’re hopeful, as you can see from the individual projections—and again, these are individual projections, not an official forecast of the Committee—we’ll be obviously very interested to see if the economy does pick up a bit and continue to reduce unemployment, as we anticipate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think one thing that’s very important for me to say is that, if you draw the conclusion that I’ve just said, that our policies—that our purchases will end in the middle of next year, you’ve drawn the wrong conclusion because our purchases are tied to what happens in the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And if the Federal Reserve makes the same error and we overestimate what’s happening, then our policies will adjust to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are not—we have no deterministic or fixed plan.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Rather, our policies are going to depend on this scenario coming true.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If it doesn’t come true, we’ll adjust our policies to that.

speaker: ALISTER BULL
sentence: Alister Bull from Reuters.

speaker: ALISTER BULL
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: ALISTER BULL
sentence: Financial conditions have tightened in the last few weeks and bond yields have gone up, and they’ve gone up again today.

speaker: ALISTER BULL
sentence: Why do you think that is?

speaker: ALISTER BULL
sentence: And could you talk a little bit about whether that rise in bond yields and interest—longer-term interest rates could affect your economic outlook and, particularly, given that mortgage rates are now back up above 4 percent, if that could affect the recovery under way in the housing market?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, that’s a good question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Yes, rates have come up some.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That’s in part due to more optimism, I think, about the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s in part due to perceptions of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The forecast—the projections that our participants submitted for this meeting, of course, were done in the last few days, so they were done with full knowledge of what had happened to financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Rates have tightened some, but, you know, other factors have been more positive—increasing house prices, for example.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think as far as the housing market is concerned, we’re going to want to watch that, but one important difference now is that people are more optimistic about housing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They expect house prices to continue to rise, and we see that, for example, in a survey question in the Michigan survey.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that, you know, compensates to some extent for a slightly higher mortgage rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, in fact, in terms of monthly payments on an average house, the change in mortgage rates we’ve seen so far is not all that dramatic.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, yes, our forecast—our projections do factor that in, and if interest rates go up for the right reasons—that is, both optimism about the economy and an accurate assessment of monetary policy—that’s a good thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That’s not a bad thing.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Robin Harding from the Financial Times.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Mr. Chairman, you’ve always argued that it’s the stock of assets that the Federal Reserve holds which affects long-term interest rates.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: How do you reconcile that with a very sharp rise in real interest rates that we’ve seen in recent weeks?

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: And do you think the market is correctly interpreting what you think is most likely to be the future path of the Federal Reserve’s stock of assets?

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, we were a little puzzled by that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It was bigger than can be explained I think by changes in the ultimate stock of asset purchases within reasonable ranges.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think we have to conclude that there are other factors at work as well, including, again, some optimism about the economy, maybe some uncertainty arising.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I’m agreeing with you that it seems larger than can be explained by a changing view of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s difficult to judge whether the markets are in sync or not.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Generally speaking though, I think that what I’ve seen from analysts and market participants is not wildly different from what, you know, the Committee is thinking and trying to—as I try today to communicate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the most important thing that I just want to convey, again, is that it’s important not to say “this date, that date, this time,” it’s important to understand that our policies are economic dependent and, in particular, if financial conditions move in a way that make this economic scenario unlikely, for example, then that would be a reason for us to adjust our policy.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: Ylan Mui, Washington Post.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: On Monday, President Obama said in an interview that he believed that you had stayed in your position as chairman for longer than you wanted to and maybe longer than you were supposed to.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: Do you agree with that assessment of your term, and can you update us on any conversations you’ve had with him about your future?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, Ylan, we just spent two days working on monetary policy issues, and I would like to keep the debate, discussion, the questions here on policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I don’t have anything for you on my personal plans.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: Greetings, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: Craig Torres from Bloomberg.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: I’d like to push for a little deeper explanation on thresholds and triggers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: The forecast and the mysterious dots kind of don’t map into the unemployment forecast.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: We see more-gradual rate rise going out into time.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: People moving to the right, at least one person, on when they expect the rate to increase, and yet, unemployment’s going to fall to 6.5 percent in 2014.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: I also note that labor force participation isn’t in that great shape, and you, in fact, have been a big believer that a lot of the exit from the workforce is related to weak demand, not structural factors.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: So here is my question.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: Can you explain a little bit more—you know—maybe is the threshold too high?

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: And I’ll point out that the Vice Chair and two other people who used to work here have done significant research on, maybe you need to let the employment rate fall much lower to pull these people back into the labor force.

speaker: CRAIG TORRES
sentence: So I’m wondering if you can expand on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, it’s a great question and—but the—what you pointed out, the difference between the little dots and the forecast actually illustrates the point, which is, remember, the 6½ percent is a threshold, not a trigger.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In other words, when we get to that point, we will then at that point begin to, you know, look at whether an increase in rates is appropriate, and among the things we would take into account, first of all, is inflation, and inflation obviously is very low and expected to stay low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Secondly, we would be taking into account, does that unemployment rate fairly represent in some sense the state of the labor market?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, as you pointed out, we have underemployment, part-time work, people leaving the labor force, reduced participation, long-term unemployment, a number of factors which suggest that maybe the 6.5 percent is a little bit—not exactly representative of the state of the labor market at that point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, first of all, since it is a threshold and not a trigger, we’re entirely free to take all that into account before we begin the process of raising rates, and that’s what the diagram suggests.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: People are saying that unemployment will be at 6.5 in late 2014 or early 2015, but they’re saying that increases in rates may not follow but several quarters after that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of adjusting the threshold, I think that’s something that might happen.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If it did happen, it would be to lower it, I’m sure, not to raise it.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Binya Appelbaum, New York Times.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Following up on that, so I understand the 6.5 percent is a threshold, but you’ve just talked about a 7 percent line for asset purchases.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: That sounded less like a threshold than like a target.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: You said if you’re at about that level, you’ll stop with the asset purchases mid next year.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: You talked about wanting to see substantial improvement in the labor market before you did suspend those purchases.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: It’s very easy to imagine a situation in which we get to 7 percent without seeing labor force participation increase.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: The employment rate’s been at the same level for three years now.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Has something changed in your thinking about the value of asset purchases?

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Why are you cutting them off before you see that “substantial improvement”?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, “substantial” is in the eye of the beholder.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think going from 8.1 percent and a stagnant rate of improvement to 7 percent and stronger economic growth is a substantial increase.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it’s important to explain that, you know, we view ourselves as having two tools.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One of them is rate policy, and that includes both setting the rate and providing guidance about future rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That’s our basic tool, that’s the one that the Federal Reserve and other central banks have used forever.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Asset purchases are a different kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They’re unconventional policy, they come with certain risks and certain uncertainties that are not necessarily associated with rate policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So our intent from the beginning, as I’ve been very clear, was to use asset purchases as a way of achieving some near-term momentum to get the economy moving forward into a sustainable recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And then, essentially, to allow the low interest rate policy which—to carry us through.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So what I—so let me just make two, I think, very important points.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The first is, our target is not 7, it’s not 6½, our target is maximum employment, which, according to our projections, most people on the Committee think is somewhere between 5 and 6 percent unemployment, and that’s where we’re trying to get to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The 7, the 6½—these are guide posts that tell you how we’re going to be shifting the mix of our tools as we try to land this ship on a, you know, on a—in a smooth way onto the aircraft carrier.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The—sorry.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, the other thing I wanted to say was that stopping asset purchases, when that happens, and I think we’re still some distance from that happening, but when that happens, that won’t involve ending the stimulus from asset purchases because we’re going to hold on to that portfolio.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And if the stock theory of the portfolio is correct, which we believe it is, holding all of those securities off of the market and reinvesting and still keeping the, you know, rolling-over maturing securities, will still continue to put downward pressure on interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, between our commitments to a low federal funds rate and the large portfolio, we will still be producing a very large amount of stimulus—in our view, enough to bring the economy smoothly towards full employment without incurring unnecessary costs or risks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: VICTORIA McGRANE.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Hi, Chairman.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Victoria McGrane with Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You, in your statement before the press conference and in the policy statement, acknowledge that inflation readings have been low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But you maintain that inflation expect—longer-term inflation expectations have remained stable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But actually, certain bond market measures of these things have fallen in recent weeks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Is that of any concern, and if not, why?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: What would you need to see for the Committee to start being more concerned that longer-term inflation expectations are, in fact, falling?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, this is something we watch very carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a number of, as I mentioned in the statement, there are a number of transitory factors that may be contributing to the very low inflation rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, the effects of the sequester on medical payments, the fact that nonmarket prices are extraordinarily low right now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So these are some things that we expect to reverse and we expect to see inflation come up a bit.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, first, on inflation expectations, it is true that the breakevens from the inflation-adjusted—inflation-indexed bonds have come down.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To this point, they still remain within the historical range that we’ve seen over the past few years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And moreover, other measures of inflation expectations, be it forecasts by professional forecasters, whether it’s survey measures from firms or households, those are all still pretty much in the same places they were.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now that being said, and as I said in my opening remarks, we don’t take anything for granted.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And one of the preconditions for the policy path that I described is that inflation begin, at least gradually, to return towards our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If that doesn’t happen, we will obviously have to take some measures to address that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we are certainly determined to keep inflation not only—we want to keep inflation near its objective, not only avoiding inflation that’s too high, but we also want to avoid inflation that’s too low.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Peter Cook with Bloomberg Television.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Given the volatility we’ve seen in the market since your comments of May 22nd, the lengths to which you are stressing the forward guidance here today, it does suggest that there are some out there you’re worried are not getting your message right now.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: And I’m wondering, to what extent do you think now that your exit strategy is going to be that much more challenging because even in this small period of time when you haven’t done all that much, you’ve seen this kind of reaction?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, it is important for us to communicate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s particularly important when we have an unusual economic situation where I think the standard relationships are not applying in the way they have, where we’re using unconventional tools, where we’re using forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I guess I agree with you that our communication is going to be very important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We hope that the—again, the key point I’ve tried to make today is that our policies are tied to how the outlook evolves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that should provide some comfort to markets because they will understand, I hope, that we will be providing whatever support is necessary.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If the economy does not improve along the lines that we expect, we’ll provide additional support.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If financial conditions evolve in a way that’s inconsistent with economic recovery, we will provide support.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we’re hope—and in that way, we hope to increase confidence both among market participants, but also among investors and private consumers and other people in the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, but again, I mean, your point is well taken that we are in a position where the simple adjustment by 25 basis points to the federal funds rate seems like a long-ago experience, and we are in a more complex type of situation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we are determined to be as clear as we can, and we hope that you and your listeners and the markets will all be able to follow what we’re saying.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Donna Borak with American Banker.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Next month will be the three-year anniversary of the Dodd–Frank Act, and, as you know, there are a number of significant rulemakings that have left to be finalized: the Volcker rule, prudential regulations under section 165 and 166, and risk retention, to name a few.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Can you provide us with an update on where we stand with the rulemakings?

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: And also, are you still optimistic that we will see these rules completed by the end of this year?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s certainly true that it’s taken time to do these regulations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a number of reasons for that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The first is that they are, inherently, many of them, quite complicated.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Volcker rule, for example, involves some very subtle distinctions between hedging and market making and proprietary trading.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The second reason is that many of them involve multiple agencies, which have to coordinate, cooperate, and agree on language.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the QRM rule is, six agencies are involved in making that rule.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the third fact—the third and basic issue is that we really have to do our homework.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have to get these right, and that means having extended comment periods, getting lots of information from the public.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And then, you know, reviewing those comments and doing all we can to make sure we’re responsive to those many, many concerns and suggestions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it does take time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it’s a little unfair to say, “Well, only 30 percent of the rules have been completed,” because most of the rules, even if they haven’t been completed, are now very far advanced, and that’s true for the major rules.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are very close, for example, to completing Basel III.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have made a good bit of progress on the Volcker rule, and I do anticipate that being done this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are making additional progress on our 165, 166 advisory rules on the capital surcharges.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: These are all things that will be coming relatively soon, at least during, you know, the current year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And of course, once they are out there, then it will still take some time to be implemented, for financial institutions to change their practices, and so on—and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would also emphasize, though, that, even as this is going on, that we are not ignoring the health and safety of the banking system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, I mean, since 2009, we’ve been doing these very rigorous stress tests, which are part of the Dodd–Frank rules.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the amount of capital that U.S. banks hold has roughly doubled—the largest banks—since 2009.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And indeed, the largest banks now appear, most of them, either to be Basel III–compliant or pretty close to Basel III–compliant.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we are working with the banks to ensure their safety, to help them move in the directions that they know they’re going to have to be going even as the rules themselves are being finalized.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, it’s an ongoing process, but I expect to see, you know, more-rapid completion, you know, going forward in the next few quarters.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Peter Barnes, Fox Business.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Sir, one of the highlights of the Kansas City Fed conference in Jackson Hole every year are remarks by the Chairman, you.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: You’re not going this year.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: We’ve heard it’s because you have a conflict in your personal schedule.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: But some have read—taken that as a sign that you may not be staying on the job for another term.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Could you comment on that?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: And could you offer us—give us a little more explanation as to why you’re not going to be in Jackson Hole for the first time?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, as I’ve said, I’m not going to comment on my personal plans, but I will say this.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think there’s a perception that the Jackson Hole conference is a Federal Reserve Systemwide conference.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s not.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s a conference sponsored by one of the 12 Reserve Banks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Every one of the 12 Reserve Banks has conferences, has meetings, and this is the one I’ve gone to the most of probably any of the Reserve Banks, so I think it’s not inappropriate to go to different conferences, different meetings, and to essentially meet all the constituents that I have in these different Reserve Banks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s one reason, certainly.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Steve Beckner of MNI, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: A number of your colleagues, as reflected in the new SEP projections, expect the unemployment rate to get down to 6½ percent next year, which is your threshold for considering raising the funds rate.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: And yet the FOMC has also said that it expects to keep rates very accommodative for a considerable time after asset purchases and after the recovery has strengthened.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: And yet here we are, the middle of 2013, you’ve not even begun to scale back asset purchases.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: So, I mean, you’ve partially addressed this.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: But, you know, could there be a conflict between, on the one hand, the asset purchase program, on the other hand, the funds rate guidance policy.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Could they conflict?

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Could you perhaps elaborate?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I certainly hope the unemployment rate comes down so fast that this becomes a problem.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I guess I would point out a couple of things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One is that, of course, you know, there’s a range of estimates, and they’re all based on each individual’s idea of optimal policy, so the policy assumptions may not be the same.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it’s true that some are as low as 6.5, but as I said in my earlier answer, that’s a threshold, not a trigger.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, evidently, if you, you know, look at the policy expectations that are given in the dot diagram, you’ll see that the very strong majority of FOMC participants still expect rates to be quite low at the end of 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s not inconsistent, that’s just saying that people are looking at a variety of factors, including inflation, which is predicted to be quite low, and other perhaps labor market factors in thinking about when it’ll be appropriate to start increasing rates.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: Thank you, Sir.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: Scott Spoerry from CNN, CNNMoney.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: Well, first of all, I should tell you that your analogy to landing the economy on an aircraft carrier worried me a little bit because, from personal experience, I find that it’s always a little bit jarring to land on an aircraft carrier.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: But I wanted to talk about mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: You mentioned during your comments here that, if I understood correctly, that you’re not going to dispose of the mortgage-backed securities that you have on the book during this period of normalization.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: And I’ve heard many people on Wall Street and elsewhere say that right now the Federal Reserve is the market for mortgage-backed securities, and so—which means that it’s kind of a warped market right now.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: And I’m just wondering, how focused are you on mortgage-backed securities and this larger world market, which—what used to be a world market for mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: And I guess—I guess what I’m saying, has the ground shifted from under us in terms of the mortgage-backed security world on a permanent basis, or at least for a very long-term basis, because of the devastating nature of what happened a few years ago?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, we are still only a fraction of the total holdings of mortgage-backed securities, but, more relevant, as part of our assessment—of our ongoing assessment of the potential costs of our various asset purchase programs, we pay very close attention to market functioning.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And our assessment is that the MBS market is still quite a healthy market in terms of the spreads, in terms of execution times, in terms of the number of people on both sides of the market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You know, there are REITs now that are building up their MBS portfolios.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are plenty of real-money investors holding MBS.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, you know, if the market was really breaking down in some way that would be a factor we’d have to take into account.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But our assessment—and, of course, we’re in that market quite a bit, so we have a lot of information about it—our assessment is that that market is still working quite well, and that our purchases are not disrupting the normal price discovery and liquidity functions of that market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think that the events of five years ago, obviously, do have a big long-term effect.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are bills in Congress that would change, reform the GSEs, for example, and ultimately would change the market for mortgage-backed securities, perhaps increasing the amount of private placements or changing the whole institutional structure of that market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we may end up holding some securities, which are in some sense left over from a previous era at some point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But nevertheless, you know, for the time being, they are the mortgage-backed securities market— Fannie and Freddie are basically it—and we are, of course, legally allowed to buy and own those securities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, we have found it useful to do that, and we believe it’s contributed to lower mortgage rates and a stronger housing market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s been our rationale.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And just, again, to come back to your question, we do not see any significant deterioration in market functioning.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If there are things that you can point us to, we would be obviously very interested.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: Well, let me just follow up with just one thing.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: In terms of the government backing through the GSEs of mortgage-backed securities, is there a concern, a legitimate concern that without government backing of this market in some way, that because the private market is—seems to move with much more rapidity than government backing and government purchases, that moving the government out of this backup role on mortgage-backed securities would be a real problem or really change the nature of getting a mortgage in America.

speaker: SCOTT SPOERRY
sentence: Some people say, you know, if the government wasn’t behind it, it would mean the end of the 30-year mortgage as we know it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, these issues are being debated.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are some—a number of bills in Congress which would change the GSEs, would eliminate them in some cases, or would place them with backstop government support, as opposed to 100 percent government credit guarantees.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So these are debates that we’re all having about the future of the U.S. mortgage market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it’s entirely possible that if there’s major change in the government’s role in the mortgage market that we might see a different structure in mortgages.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, you know, other countries have different structures, and they have, in many cases, the same or similar home ownership rates as we do, so it’s possible that we may find that a different structure is better for some people.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb, MarketWatch.com.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I was wondering if you could go back over your—what you said about the plans for tapering later this year.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And why isn’t tapering a tightening?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: It seems that many people in the markets just as soon as you talk taper—will taper—are just going to push forward when you—they think that first rate hike will come.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, as I tried to explain in my opening remarks, our plans depend on the economic scenario and how it evolves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And what I tried to do is explain how our asset purchases would evolve if, sort of, the modal, the most likely forecast, were to, in fact, take place, which, of course, it won’t exactly take place, something else will no doubt happen.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But again, our basic forecast is one which is basically, as was pointed out earlier by Mr. Hilsenrath, a moderately optimistic forecast, where growth picks up as we pass through this period of fiscal restraint; where unemployment continues to fall at a gradual pace as it has been since last September—and we have made some progress since last September; and inflation rises slowly towards 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Those are the conditions that define this sort of baseline forecast.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In that case then, as I described it, we would expect probably to slow or moderate purchases some time later this year, and then through the middle of—through the early part of next year, and ending, in that scenario, somewhere in the middle of the year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Again though, it’s very important to understand that that’s—if we do that, that would basically say that, you know, that we’ve had a relatively decent economic outcome in terms of sustained improvement in growth and unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If things are worse, we would do more.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If things are better, we will do less.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think I would—to answer your other question—I would draw the analogy: If the Federal Reserve in normal times lowers the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, but some traders think that—were expecting 50 basis points, then there might be a sense that the financial conditions have tightened somewhat.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But nevertheless, I think you would say that if the Fed cut the funds rate by 25 basis points, that that was an easing of policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, by the same token, as long as we’re buying assets, we are adding to our holdings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do believe—although, you know, there’s room for debate—we do believe that the primary effect of our purchases is through the stock that we hold, because that stock has been withdrawn from markets, and the prices of those assets have to adjust to balance supply and demand.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we’ve taken out some of the supply, and so the prices go up, the yields go down.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, that, seems to me, consistent with the idea that we’re still adding liquidity, we’re still adding accommodation to the system.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: Ryan Avent, The Economist.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Hi.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: Mr. Chairman, I’m trying to sort of understand the view with relation to these inflation figures.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: I’m a little surprised at how, I guess, blasé the Committee seems about them, with the exception of President Bullard.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: Inflation looks remarkably low on both core and headline, PCE and CPI.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: Your projections have it at—rising, the core PCE rising, to at most 2 percent in 2015.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: You say that inflation expectations have remained sort of within the range that the Fed has traditionally been comfortable with, but they have fallen by a good ½ percentage point.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: And, as you know, that when interest rates are stuck at the zero lower bound, a decline in inflation expectations sort of translates into an increase in real rates.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: Why is the Fed not more concerned about this?

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: It seems to me that earlier in the recovery, they were more concerned about declines in inflation like this.

speaker: RYAN AVENT
sentence: And wouldn’t you say that, even if you’re happy with the pace of labor market recovery, that, other things equal, this sort of inflation performance suggests that you should be pushing harder on the accelerator.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I don’t disagree with anything you said.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think low—inflation that’s too low is a problem.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It increases the risk of deflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It raises real interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It means that debt deleveraging takes place more slowly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, there’s always issues about, you know, why is it low?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, as I pointed out, there are a few reasons that are probably not that meaningful economically—for example, the temporary movement in medical prices, the temporary movements in nonmarket prices, things of that sort.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, after all, the CPI is somewhat higher.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so we expect inflation to come back up, that’s our forecast.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I don’t want—I think it’s entirely wrong to say we’re not concerned about it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are concerned about it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We would like to get inflation up to our target, and that will be a factor in our thinking about the thresholds.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It will be a factor in our thinking about asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, you know, we’ve got a dual mandate, and it’s maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And there’s a reason why we define price stability as a positive inflation rate, not zero, because we believe that in order to best maximize the mandate, we need to have enough inflation so that there is, in fact, you know, some room for real interest rates to move.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I don’t disagree with your basic argument.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Thanks, Mr. Chairman, Kevin Hall with McClatchy Newspapers.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Since you’ve referred to Mr. Hilsenrath, is he the real power behind the throne?

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: That’s one of the questions we all have.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: You had mentioned on several occasions now that quantitative easing is designed to kind of spur economic—drive down the yields, force more risk-taking that flows through the economy.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: There had been debate a couple of years ago at the beginning of this about whether it was inflating commodity prices.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Inflation as a whole is subdued, but oil prices are—anchored somewhere around $99—$93 to $99.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: We were told once we have domestic production—we have record production now—that that would be a signal to bring prices down.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: It hasn’t happened.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: Brazil has got people on the streets because of inflation.

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: To what degree do you think quantitative easing is actually inflating commodity prices, and have you been able to filter that out?

speaker: KEVIN HALL
sentence: And any thoughts on wage growth and why that’s been so flat when everything else seems to be doing good in the economy?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, when we—as I recall, I believe I have this right—when we introduced the second round of LSAPs, properly known as QE2, in, I think, November 2010, there was a lot of increase in commodity prices at that time, and there was a lot of complaining that the Fed is pumping up commodity prices, and that that’s a negative for people around the world.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we argued at the time that the effects of the Federal Reserve’s policy on global commodity prices was probably pretty small, and that it operated—to the extent it did have an effect—it operated through growth—mostly through growth expectations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That is, a stronger global economy tends to drive up commodity prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: This time around, we’ve purchased, and are in the process of purchasing, a lot more than we did in so-called QE2.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We haven’t really seen much increase in commodity prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Commodity prices are way off their peaks of early last year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Oil is a little bit different from others in that it’s kind of hung up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But many other commodity prices have fallen further, and the reason I would give for that is that the emerging markets—China, the rest of Asia, and some other parts of the world—plus Europe, of course, are softer, and so global commodity demand is weaker.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that explains, I think, the bulk of why commodity prices have not risen so much.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think that’s all consistent with our story that the effect of asset purchases on commodity prices—I’m not saying it’s zero, but I don’t think that it’s nearly as big as some folks have suggested.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of wages, I think that’s mostly consistent with our view that unemployment, at 7.6 percent, is still pretty far from where we should be satisfied.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Maximum employment, we think, is, again, between 5 and 6 percent, although these are very difficult numbers to estimate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, very weak wage growth, except in a few places and a few narrow occupations, is indicative to me of a labor market that remains quite slack and where, you know, that justifies, I think—together with low inflation—justifies why we are maintaining a highly accommodative policy.

speaker: KATE DAVIDSON
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Kate Davidson from Politico.

speaker: KATE DAVIDSON
sentence: The SEC’s money market fund proposal is far less comprehensive than the plan that you and the Financial Stability Oversight Council endorsed.

speaker: KATE DAVIDSON
sentence: Do you think FSOC should defer to the SEC or still press for more to be done?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I’m very glad to see that the SEC has taken up money market reform.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It is by far the best outcome for the SEC to do it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s the area where they have the expertise and where they have the experience.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of their actual proposal they’ve put out—of course, it’s just a proposal for comment—one of their two proposals, the floating NAV, the floating net asset value, is, of course, qualitatively similar to that—one of the proposals that was in the FSOC suggestions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have not yet reviewed this in enough detail to give a view.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I hope that—I think—I know for sure that by putting out a floating NAV proposal that they’re moving in the right direction.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I’m hopeful that what comes out will be something that’s sufficient to meet the very important need of stabilizing the money market funds.

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: I’m Akio Fujii, Nikkei Newspaper.

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: Thank you, Chairman.

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: Recently, we have seen great volatility in Japanese market—equity, JGB, and foreign exchange.

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: Some say this volatility is due to uncertainty to the Federal Reserve’s monetary policy direction, but others say this is due to lack of confidence to the Bank of Japan’s monetary policy.

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: So how do you view the Bank of Japan’s efforts?

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: Do you still support Bank of Japan policy?

speaker: AKIO FUJII
sentence: And other question is, how much do you pay attention to the spillover effect to the international market when you consider exit strategy?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think the volatility is mostly linked to the Bank of Japan’s efforts, and that would seem logical, since in earlier episodes, when the Fed was doing asset purchases and the BOJ was not doing anything, there was no volatility.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it sort of seems logical that the change here is the change in BOJ policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The BOJ is fighting against a very difficult, entrenched deflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, of course, deflation has been a problem in Japan for many, many years, which means that expectations are very much—the public’s expectations are for continuing deflation, and therefore it takes very aggressive policies to break those expectations and to get inflation up to the 2 percent target that the Bank of Japan has set.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s why it’s difficult, they’ve had to be very aggressive.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That aggressiveness in the early stages of this process, where investors are still learning about the BOJ’s reaction function, it’s not all that surprising that there’s volatility.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Also, the JGB markets are less liquid than, say, the Treasury market, for example.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I—you know, I think that’s something they need to pay close attention to, but, on the whole, I think that it is important for Japan to attack deflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I also agree with the “three arrows,” the idea that besides breaking deflation, it’s important to address fiscal and structural issues as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I’m supportive of my colleague, Mr. Kuroda, and I’m supportive of what Japan is doing, even though it does have some effects on our economy as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The—there are a lot of reasons why emerging markets and other countries experience capital inflows and volatility.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Some of them have to do with changes in growth expectations.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, we’ve seen a lot of changes in growth patterns in the emerging markets recently.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Some of it has to do with risk-on, risk-off behavior, and some of it probably does have to do with monetary policy in advanced economies, which includes, of course, the United States.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do take it—pay attention to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I frequently meet with colleagues from emerging markets at the G-20, for example, and we discuss these issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the right way to think about it is that, as the G-7 and the G-20 both have noted, that what U.S. monetary policy, like that of Japan, is trying to do is trying to help this economy grow.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And a global recovery, a global—strong global growth depends very much on the U.S. growing at a reasonable rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, while there is some effect, I think the net effect, including a stronger U.S. economy, is, on the whole, positive, and I think most of my colleagues in emerging markets recognize that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, anything we can do through communication or other means to try to minimize any overflow effects or side effects, we will certainly do.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Hello Mr. Chairman, Mark Hamrick with Bankrate.com.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: You know, you’ve talked about being in uncharted territory with policy, and we can remember that these news conferences just began about two years ago as well, and so there’s that mix of communication and policy.

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Insofar as the FOMC decided not to include the information about adjusting the asset purchases today, how do you walk that fine line?

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: And why did the FOMC decide essentially to leave it to you to describe that, as opposed to putting it down in its own words?

speaker: MARK HAMRICK
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, again, we don’t think of this as a change in policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: What I was deputized to do, if you will, was to try to make somewhat clearer the implications of our existing policy and to try to explain better how the policy would evolve in various economic scenarios, and that’s a little bit difficult to put into, you know, a very terse FOMC statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now that being said, going forward, I think that, you know, some of these elements, to the extent that we can make them useful, will begin to appear in the FOMC statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s entirely possible.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But it seemed like the right tactic in this case to explain these fairly subtle contingencies in a context where I could answer questions and respond to any misunderstandings that might occur.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you.
